images.caption: Figure 1:Our WSL process. First, the retriever identifies the top-kùëòkitalic_kcandidate senses (Candidate Generation). Then, the reader identifies the spans to be disambiguated (Concept Detection) and pairs each of these with their most suitable sense (Word Sense Disambiguation).

header: Appendix CEvaluation of SemCor with ConSeCHEUAnnotations

images.caption: Figure 2:The counts of four POS categories (NOUN, VERB, ADJ, ADV) for three different datasets (Senseval2, Senseval3, Semeval2015). Each POS category is subdivided into ‚ÄôOLD‚Äô (blue) and ‚ÄôNEW‚Äô (orange) data points, indicating the frequency of each annotation before and after our comprehensive annotation process.

Figure 3:The count of POS categories for the Semeval2007 and Semeval2013 datasets. Notably, the original Semeval2007 dataset lacks annotations for ADJ and ADV categories, and Semeval2013 lacks annotations for VERB, ADJ, and ADV, as indicated by the absence of ‚ÄôOLD‚Äô (blue) bars for these categories. The ‚ÄôNEW‚Äô (orange) bars represent the counts post-annotation.

Figure 4:The counts of four POS categories within the ‚ÄôALL‚Äô dataset, which aggregates data across multiple sources. The ‚ÄôOLD‚Äô (blue) bars represent the original annotation counts, while the ‚ÄôNEW‚Äô (orange) bars indicate the increased counts following our extensive annotation process.
